artifact_name: mummy-case; cartonnage; human mummy; amulet; pectoral; heart-scarab
Description: Mummified remains of an adult woman, Chantress of Amun and Lady of the House, named Tayesmutengebtiu, also called Tamut, in painted cartonnage casing with a gilded face. On her cartonnage case, she is also called Tjenetmutgebty and Tjenetmutgebtiu. Sex: female Age: Middle Adult (35-49 years old) Stature: 158.9 ± 1.9 cm Summary: Mummy of adult woman Tayesmutengebtiu, with wrappings in a cartonnage case. Head and neck - Mouth slightly open, all teeth present, showing advanced dental attrition. Artificial eyes inserted in the orbits. Cervical spine appears intact. Under the chin, over the neck, there is a metal amulet in the form of a kneeling goddess with wings. Brain extracted through nasal passage, and skull cavity filled with textile. Packing in mouth, cheeks and throat. Short hair. Chest and Abdomen – Flank incision on left side with two plates incised with an eye of Horus covering the opening. Filled with bundles of textile and packing material, and four parcels, probably containing organs, that enclose wax figurines in the shape of the Sons of Horus. Over the sternum there is a pectoral of metal in the form of a falcon with outstretched wings. A small heart-scarab lies beneath the pectoral. The lateral view shows that the amulets, scarab, and pectoral lie either on the skin surface or on the very innermost bandages. On the left arm is a metallic plaque, incised with a standing deity, and a bead. On the right arm is a bead. There is another metallic plate in the shape of a vulture located on the pubic area. Cluster of small amulets on the abdomen, probably linked by a thread, including a djed-pillar, a wedjat-eye and a tit-girdle. She also wears stola and pendants, very close to the skin, with a metallic rectangular strip placed over the abdomen. Arms - Extended. Hands with extended fingers over the pubic area. Legs – Extended with the feet at a right angle. Across the top of both feet lies a metallic amulet in the form of a winged scarab holding the sun's disc between its front legs and a smaller disc between its hind legs. Nails of fingers and toes are covered with thin rectangular sheets of metal. Pathological conditions – atherosclerosis in the femoral arteries, periapical lesion on the upper left first premolar. Bandages – Body wrapped into a bundle, arms and legs not wrapped separately, with evidence of resinous material applied in at least two instances between layers of wrappings. Cartonnage case – Gilded face surrounded by a vulture type wig, broad collar on the chest, and several registers showing rows of standing gods separated by winged deities. Back decorated with large djed-pillar held by Isis, with string used to close the cartonnage partly visible. Condition Preservation skull: 100.0% Dentition: 100% Preservation post cranial: 100% Condition: Excellent – complete with little to no breakage Soft tissues or other: extensive, see summary Percentage mummified skull: 100% Percentage mummified post cranial: 100%

Moreno (2023), Cardiovascular disease in Nile valley mummies: exploring the need for a more systematic approach that accounts for vessel prevalence, links to oral health and the impact of Dual Energy CT scanning. In M. Binder, C.A. Roberts and D. Antoine, The Bioarchaeology of cardiovascular disease. Cambridge, 98-129.
